awd_titl_txt: Transcriptomics Profiling of Vertebral Fusion in Evolution and Development
awd_abstract_narration:
During normal maturation of the spine, vertebrae fuse together to form the sacrum in the pelvic girdle. In birds, spine fusion is more extensive, with approximately half of the vertebrae are fused into compound bony structures. Increased fusion in birds arose during evolution as an adaptation for flight. The biological mechanisms responsible for normal vertebral fusion are largely unknown. However, using the chicken as a model organism, the PI made the surprising discovery that sterile inflammation drives fusion in the tail. Inflammation is generally a response to disease or trauma, but here the PI uncovered a novel role for sterile inflammation in normal bone development. The PI inhibited inflammation with corticosteroids, and found that this treatment inhibits tail fusion, demonstrating a previously unknown effect of corticosteroids on spine maturation. The implications for these findings are vast, not just for avian evolution but for axial development across vertebrates, and for the possible side effects of corticosteroid treatment in humans. For this project, the PI will determine whether inflammation is a common driver of normal vertebral fusion, or whether multiple mechanisms have evolved for this process. Additionally, as part of a long-standing collaboration, the PI will link the genomics capabilities of Montana State University and Clemson University.

This Research Infrastructure Improvement Track-4 EPSCoR Research Fellows (RII Track-4:NSF) project would provide a fellowship to an Assistant Research Professor at Montana State University (MSU). This work would be conducted in collaboration with researchers at Clemson University. The goals of this proposal are to receive transcriptomics training, to test the hypothesis that sterile inflammation is a universal driver of vertebral fusion, and to promote Clemson University’s genomics facility to Montana State University researchers. The PI will compare the transcriptional profiles of fusing chicken synsacrum intervertebral disc tissues to caudal non-fusing tissue by whole transcriptome RNAseq. Specifically, the PI will investigate the potential contributions of nucleus pulposus disc structures and inflammatory response to fusion in different axial regions of the chicken. These data will assess if ankylosis occurs via common or independent mechanisms, and will lend insight into avian axial evolution. Clemson University is ideal for these studies not only for its genomics facility, but also for its poultry farm, one of the few research poultry centers in academia. Training will include RNA extraction methods and bioinformatics analysis, including GO and KEGG profiling. The expertise gleaned from this collaboration will be applied to an RNAseq instructional module that will be built for MSU researchers to utilize Clemson’s genomics facility. MSU currently offers microarray, but not RNAseq services. These proposed studies will allow the PI to resolve vertebral fusion mechanism(s) in birds and ultimately expand the PI’s investigations to normal and pathological fusion in a variety of vertebrates, including mammalian disease models. Undergraduate mentorship and public education of science are deeply rooted in this project. The PI will continue to train existing students, recruit additional undergraduates, and pursue multiple and varied outreach efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

 

Project Title: Transcriptomics Profiling of Vertebral Fusion in Evolution and Development
PI: Dana Rashid
Awardee: Montana State University
Award Number: 2229308

 

Montana State University was awarded an RII Track IV grant titled “Transcriptomics profiling of vertebral fusion in evolution and development”. The long-established collaboration between myself (Dana Rashid, Montana State University) and Dr. Susan Chapman (Clemson University) has led to the discovery that inflammation has contributed to the evolution of skeletal adaptations in avian dinosaurs. This project supported two aims: 1) for me to receive bulk RNA-seq training at Clemson University, and 2) for me to assemble a bulk RNA-seq manual for Montana researchers. Both aims were accomplished, and the resulting data supports our hypothesis that inflammation is a common driver of vertebral ankylosis. Also, the data was leveraged to obtain one million dollars of additional project funding.

 

RNA-seq training and data collection. Training for bulk RNA-seq included tissue processing, RNA extraction, rRNA depletion, cDNA library production and sequencing, data processing, and differential expression analyses. Under Dr. Chapman’s supervision and with training provided by the Clemson University Genomics and Bioinformatics Facility (CUGBF) and New England Biolabs, I generated and analyzed bulk RNA-seq data for avian sacral fusion.

 

The resulting bulk RNA-seq data set for chicken sacral fusion suggests gene expression that is consistent with early-stage inflammation. More RNA-seq experiments will be performed to characterize different stages of the inflammatory process, but the data supports our hypothesis that inflammation drives avian sacral fusion. This result is significant because sacral fusion is common to most terrestrial vertebrates. Fused sacra are observed in late Carboniferous/Early Permian amniote fossils at the split of reptiles and mammals, and we posit that the fusion mechanism has been inherited by these two major groups of vertebrates from their early amniote ancestors. By studying sacral fusion in birds, therefore, we are likely identifying the sacral fusion mechanism in a wide variety of living animals. In addition, due to the similarities we observe between tail and sacral ankylosis, the data supports our hypothesis that inflammation is a universal driver of vertebral fusion. Necroptosis is another important contributor to fusion that is indicated in our RNA-seq data. Necroptosis is a type of cell death that can initiate inflammation, and is a process that had not been identified in normal development before our studies. We suspect that a universal vertebral fusion mechanism involving necroptosis was co-opted from the more ancient bone fracture repair process during vertebrate evolution.

 

In addition to RNA-seq, we performed microCT and histology analyses on anti-inflammatory corticosteroid-treated chicken sacral fusion. These data also support our hypothesis that inflammation drives developmental bone fusion events. Corticosteroid treatment inhibited vertebral fusions, suggesting that treatment regimens involving these anti-inflammatory drugs should be evaluated for their possible effects on axial maturation in children and adolescents.

 

Our study on inflammation’s involvement in avian tail vertebral fusion was published during the timeframe of the grant. We are currently assembling two manuscripts on data collected for this grant, one on avian sacral fusion and another on the evolutionary changes in the avian vertebral formula.

 

RNA-seq manual. To increase research infrastructure at Montana State University and to facilitate coordination between MSU and Clemson universities, I wrote the “Bulk RNA-seq Instructional Manual”. This manual is posted on the MSU Cellular Analysis Core Facility website (https://www.montana.edu/mbi/facilities/cellular-analysis-core/additional-resources/documents/Bulk-RNAseq-Instructional-Manual.pdf).  Versions of the manual were also provided for University of Montana and Clemson University. The steps required for RNA-seq, from experimental design to differential gene analysis, are discussed. The manual was written as a practical guide for performing bulk RNA-seq, and as a reference for understanding the data processing work flow.

 

I am now serving as a bulk RNA-seq consultant for MSU researchers, and will continue to update the manual henceforth. I promote interactions between RNA-seq-interested researchers at MSU with Clemson’s genomics facility, as well as relevant coursework. Bioinformatics training of students continues in my own laboratory.

 

Career advancement. The training received and data collected from this grant has greatly impacted my science and career goals. I presented our data at the Society for Avian Paleontology and Evolution meeting in Malaga, Spain, in 2023, and have incorporated our findings into undergraduate class lectures at MSU. With my collaborators Susan Chapman and Kim Cooper (UC San Diego), we leveraged this data to obtain a $1m W.M. Keck Foundation award. This Keck award has led to a state-sponsored appointment for me in my department. The award is allowing us to greatly expand the project in personnel and research scope.
